en_first_half: While they were at breakfast the letters were brought in. Among the rest there was one
en_second_half: for Colonel Brandon;—he took it, looked at the direction, changed colour, and immediately left the room.
en_results: from the gentleman himself, reproaching her for not having seen him before she went out, and requesting the
en_results_raw: from the gentleman himself, reproaching her for not having seen him before she went out, and requesting the pleasure of her company to take a turn about the shrubbery, before the morning grew too hot. Elizabeth was pleased to see his account, and to observe that his resentment was nothing in comparison to her own. She was angry with herself for being so silly as to hope for any thing from him, and yet she could not help it. She had never seen a man so much in love before; and she could not help but fancy that he must be very agreeable, and that it was a great pity that he should be so blinded by his vanity. She was in hopes that he would soon get over it, and that they might all be happy together again.

She closed the instrument, and walked away; and though the room was very still, her agitation was so great that she could not sit down; could not seat herself quietly in any attitude. She was up and down the room, and in and out of it, and even to the very door, in search of something that would do, something that would make her feel less wretched. Her eyes were towards the window, and she saw the snow falling thick and fast, and she felt a wish to be out in it, to be in the quiet and solitude of the falling snow, to be anywhere but within the four walls of that room, where every object seemed to remind her of him, and every sound to be a memento of his voice. She opened the door, and went out into the passage, and from thence to the stairs, and down them to the hall, and through the hall to the door, and out of the house, and into the snow, and then she felt a little better, a little more at peace. The cold air and the falling snow seemed to calm her, and she walked on, not knowing where she was going, or what she was doing, but feeling that she must move, that she could not be still. She walked on, till she came to the end of the village, and then she turned, and began to walk back again, and as she walked, she felt her heart grow lighter, and her spirits begin to revive. She thought of Willoughby, and of all that had passed, and she felt a sense of peace and resignation, a sense of being reconciled to her fate, and of being able to bear it. And when she got back to the house, she went up stairs, and to her room, and sat down, and was still, and felt that she could be still, and that she could bear to be alone.

I have seen many descriptions of the picturesque, and of late, I have seen many pictures, but I must confess, I have yet to see the picturesque in nature, or to feel any thing like admiration, or even pleasure, in those scenes, which are so lavishly extolled by the admirers of the picturesque. I have seen the mountains, and the vallies, and the rivers, and the lakes, and I have admired their grandeur, and their beauty, but I have not felt that deep and solemn emotion, which is said to be the result of the picturesque. His arrival was always announced by the sound of his horse's hoofs on the gravel sweep in front of the house, and in a moment he would be heard at the door, making his cheerful greetings to the footman, and then to the family, as he entered the drawing-room.

She saw that Mr. Rushworth was not without his good qualities, and that his pride and haughtiness were not entirely the result of his own conceit, but partly the effect of the foolish partiality of his wife, who, in her excessive fondness for her own beauty, had instilled into his mind a most unreasonable and unjust idea of his own importance. She was, however, too well bred, and too much accustomed to the society of well mannered people, to be put out of her way by it, or to make any pointed observation upon it. "I am sure they will bring some news of the regiment," said she, as she returned to the breakfast table. "I dare say they will," replied Elinor, "and I am glad of it, for I am quite tired of this dull life we have been leading here. I long to hear of something more interesting than the price of wheat, and the number of acres that have been sown." "I am sure you do," said Marianne, "and I am glad you have something to look forward to. I am afraid I shall not be so fortunate, for I have no expectation of any news that can interest me." "Oh, come, Marianne," said Elinor, "do not be so gloomy. I dare say you will find something to amuse you, if you will only look for it. And who knows but what may happen before the day is out. We may have some unexpected visitor, or some news may arrive that will surprise us all." "I do not know," said Marianne, "but I think it is unlikely. We are so far from every thing here, that I do not see how any thing interesting can happen." "We shall see," said Elinor, "and I am determined to make the most of the day, and to find some amusement if I can." en_first_half: "You must not talk so, Marianne. Have you no comforts? no friends? Is your loss such as leaves no opening for consolation? Much as you suffer now, think of what you would have suffered if the discovery of his character had been delayed
en_second_half: to a later period—if your engagement had been carried on for months and months, as it might have been, before he chose to put an end to it. Every additional day of unhappy confidence, on your side, would have made the blow more dreadful."
en_results: to a later period—and your attachment had been strengthened by time, and his affection and wishes, though late, had been ardent and sincere! Think of your sister; think of her miserable condition, and the alleviation that it would be in your
en_results_raw: to a later period—and your attachment had been strengthened by time, and his affection and wishes, though late, had been ardent and sincere! Think of your sister; think of her miserable condition, and the alleviation that it would be in your power to afford her. Your feelings may be the first object of your consideration, but it is not very wonderful that, with a strong affection, and a lively mind, you should be deeply affected by the discovery of his character. But do not suppose that I am less sensible to your distress, because I urge the necessity of self-command. You must learn to govern your feelings, and be even in your own eyes, the same creature, as you have ever been in mine. I have faith in you. Let us do our duty, and have comfort in it, and that comfort will be always left us, if we do it. I shall now leave you to your sister, and I hope you will be able to join us at dinner. I wish you could, and I dare say, you would, if you knew how much you would strengthen me. I am not strong, and I wish to be able to support you, and your sister, and all of us, as we ought to be supported. I am not strong, but I shall do my best, and I hope you will do yours, and that together we shall be able to bear what we have to bear, and to do what we have to do.

en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

I only hope it may not be more than can be undone. I hope you do not think me too anxious, as a relation, in this affair. On the contrary, if I have gone too far, it has been from a conviction of its being my duty; and I should be led by the same principle if there were more to do. But I hope there is not. I hope, and I say it with the utmost sincerity, that your sister may be more fortunate than I dare to expect; and that you will never find it necessary to regret my having taken so active a part in the affair, by thinking it necessary for her sake to make the result known to you. I should be miserable, indeed, if I were to lose the confidence you have placed in me, in any respect. But I am sure I shall not; and that, in the end, you will not think my interference, in the affair, to have been at least injudicious or unkind. There was a necessity for my interfering, which I hope, in time, you will see the reasonableness of. I will not now enter into particulars, but I assure you, and I pledge myself to you, to give you a full explanation, whenever you desire it. And as a pledge of it, I am now going to take my leave for a week or two, and when I return, I hope to bring you more certain information on the subject, and more matters relating to your sister and family, which I have reason to suppose you would wish to hear. This will not do as a good excuse for my going away without seeing you again; but as I really must go, and cannot do otherwise, I hope this will be some excuse for my taking leave of you in such a manner.

en_results_raw: tell him, if I were to see him. I do not suppose he has a bed to lie on, or a chair to sit on. Here, take my keys, and go and see if you can find him, and bring him to my house, and I will take care of him." The servant, who had been waiting at the door, now took the keys, and went in search of the young man, while Mrs. Jennings sat down to rest herself, and to think of the best way to assist him. She was a woman of great kindness and benevolence, and was always ready to help those in distress. She had a large house, and was well able to afford to give a home to the young man, and to provide for all his wants. She thought that it would be a great pleasure to her to have him with her, and to be able to assist him in his trouble. She was sure that he would be very grateful to her, and that he would do all in his power to repay her kindness. She was so much engaged in her thoughts, that she did not hear the servant when he came back, and it was not until he spoke to her, that she knew of his return. "I have found him, ma'am," said the servant, "and I have brought him with me." "Very well," said Mrs. Jennings, "bring him in, and let me see him." The servant now went out, and soon returned with the young man, who looked very pale and ill. Mrs. Jennings was shocked when she saw him, and she could not help exclaiming, "Good heavens! how ill you do look!" The young man tried to speak, but he was too weak, and he could only bow his head, and look at her with eyes full of gratitude. Mrs. Jennings was so much moved by his appearance, that she could not help tears coming into her eyes, and she was obliged to turn away to hide them. She soon, however, regained her composure, and turning to the young man, she said, "Come, you must go to bed, and I will send you some dinner, and you shall be well taken care of, I assure you." The young man bowed his head again, and followed the servant out of the room, while Mrs. Jennings sat down to think of the best way to assist him, and to make him happy.

en_first_half: "Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her. The merest awkward country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.— I remember her perfectly. Just the kind of girl I should suppose likely to captivate poor Edward. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the
en_second_half: breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier—I think it is most probable—that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;—that is certain; absolutely starved."

es_first_half: —Sí, una vez, cuando estaba alojada en esta casa. Me había dejado caer por unos diez minutos, y me bastó con lo que vi de ella. Una simple muchacha pueblerina, desmañada, sin estilo ni elegancia, y casi sin ningún atractivo. La recuerdo perfectamente. Justo el tipo de muchacha que habría creído capaz de cautivar al pobre Edward. Apenas mi madre me contó todo el asunto, de inmediato me ofrecí— a hablarle, a disuadirlo de la unión; pero, según pude darme cuenta, ya era demasiado tarde para hacer algo, pues por desgracia no estuve ahí en los primeros momentos y no supe nada
es_second_half: de lo ocurrido hasta después de la ruptura, cuando, ya sabe usted, no me correspondía interferir. Pero si se me hubiera informado unas pocas horas antes, probablemente habría podido hacer algo. De todas maneras le habría hecho ver las cosas a Edward con toda claridad. “Mi querido amigo”, le habría dicho, “piensa en lo que haces. Estás comprometiéndote en la más desafortunada unión, que toda tu familia desaprueba de manera unánime”. En fin, no puedo evitar pensar que habría encontrado alguna manera de lograrlo. Pero ahora es demasiado tarde. Debe estar muerto de hambre, sabe usted; con toda seguridad, absolutamente muerto de hambre.

Pero, como ya he dicho, todo esto ocurrió hace mucho tiempo, y ahora mi hermano está casado con otra mujer, y parece muy feliz. A pesar de todo, no pude evitar sentir una punzada de celos al ver a mi hermano tan enamorado de su nueva esposa. Me di cuenta de que la vida es muy extraña, y que a veces las cosas no salen como uno las planea. Pero, al fin y al cabo, lo que importa es que mi hermano sea feliz, y eso es lo que me importa a mí.
